data.title: Ukraine capital: Why you should say Kyiv not Kiev - and it's because of Putin
data.meta_description: UKRAINE is locked in an ongoing battle against Russia's rule, and now the correct spelling of its capital has never been more important. Here's why you should say Kyiv not Kiev.
data.text:
Ukraine chief explodes at Germany over Russia snub

Ukraine is in the midst of a terrifying crisis. With Russian troops on their doorstep, this eastern European democracy is desperately trying and defend its sovereignty. As Ukraine tries to tear itself away from Russian influence, it has never been more important to refer to the capital as Kyiv, not Kiev. Here’s why spelling matters.

“Kyiv” is the official Latin transliteration of the capital’s name in the Ukrainian language.

“Kiev” derives from the Russian way of pronouncing the city’s name.

Vladimir Putin has continued to push the Russian spelling and pronunciation of the Ukrainian capital, despite Ukraine’s attempts to revert it to its original spelling.

Until recently the international community has widely used the spelling “Kiev,” but with an estimated 100,000 Russian troops on Ukraine’s border, the country’s independence is under threat.

READ MORE: Expert warns Putin's Ukraine plan could put Russia in 'real trouble'

Therefore, it has never been more important to use refer to the capital as Kyiv to recognise Ukraine's independence from President Putin’s controlling regime.

Dr Yuri Shevchuk told the New York Times: “There’s no reason other than old colonialist inertia to continue using a Russian spelling for a Ukrainian city name.”

How do you pronounce Kyiv?

Speaking to the New York Times in 2019, Dr Shevchuk explained how to pronounce Kyiv properly.

He said native Ukrainians stress the first vowel. The "i" is pronounced similarly to the “i” in “kid” or “lid.”

Mr Shevchuk added the second vowel is pronounced as a separate syllable and sounds like the “ee” sound in “keel.”

And the v is also pronounced like the end of the word “low.”

In comparison, the Russian 'Kiev' is pronounced like Kee-ef

Increasingly, western media is adopting the Ukrainian-language derived “Kyiv” as their official spelling for the country’s capital.

The Wall Street Journal, the Washington Post, the Telegraph, and the BBC have all ditched the Russian-rooted “Kiev” in solidarity with Ukrainian’s desire to ditch the Russian influence still gripping their country.

But this isn’t a recent revelation - in the 1990s the Ukrainian authorities tried to endorse “Kyiv” as the correct spelling for their capital, Atlantic Council reports.

This was done in light of a wider drive to assert a Ukrainian identity after the country broke away from the Soviet Union.

Ukraine became an independent state in 1991 and has since tried to reverse the so-called “Russification” of their country.

Ukraine has long been under the influence of Russia.

Under the Russian Empire and later the Soviet State, the use of the Ukrainian language in print was often outlawed and words altered to firm up Russian linguistic and political positions in the country.

Since becoming independent Ukrainian authorities have tried to change other place names with their original names, however, this wasn't met with much success.

Outside of diplomatic protocol, the international community didn’t pay much attention to Ukraine’s desire to take back its identity by reverting place names to their original Ukrainian spellings.

This has meant that the better known “Kiev” has largely stuck.

When Russia backed separatists in eastern Ukraine and aggressively annexed Crimea in 2014, a fresh bid was made to try and change the spelling of the capital for good.

The Ukrainian Foreign Ministry launched a social media campaign to try and achieve this.

The campaign called on social media users to use the hashtags #CorrectUA and #KyivNotKiev and asked international media to switch from “Kiev” to “Kyiv”.

Thankfully, people are becoming increasingly aware of the significance of this spelling and are ditching the Russian “Kiev” out of respect for Ukrainians.
